/lit/ is for the discussion of literature, specifically books (fiction & non-fiction), short stories, poetry, creative writing, etc. If you want to discuss history, religion, or the humanities, go to /his/. If you want to discuss politics, go to /pol/. Philosophical discussion can go on either /lit/ or /his/, but those discussions of philosophy that take place on /lit/ should be based around specific philosophical works to which posters can refer.

Check the wiki, the catalog, and the archive before asking for advice or recommendations, and please refrain from starting new threads for questions that can be answered by a search engine.

/lit/ is a slow board! Please take the time to read what others have written, and try to make thoughtful, well-written posts of your own. Bump replies are not necessary.

>Write me a fantasy short story

Once upon a time, in a land far, far away, there was a kingdom ruled by a wise and benevolent king. The people of the kingdom were happy and prosperous, and the land was filled with beauty and wonder.

But there was one dark cloud on the horizon. For many years, the kingdom had been under attack by a fierce and powerful dragon, who would swoop down from the mountains and steal treasure and livestock from the people. The dragon was cunning and fierce, and no one had ever been able to defeat it.

The king and his bravest knights had tried many times to slay the dragon, but each time they failed. The people of the kingdom grew desperate and fearful, and many of them began to lose hope.

But one day, a young and fearless warrior arrived in the kingdom. She was known for her skill with a sword and her quick thinking, and she had come to the kingdom to challenge the dragon.

The king and his knights were skeptical at first, but the young warrior was determined. She trained day and night, honing her skills and preparing for the fight of her life.

When the day of the battle arrived, the young warrior faced the dragon with courage and determination. The two fought a fierce and bloody battle, but in the end, the young warrior emerged victorious. She had slain the dragon, and the kingdom was saved.

The people of the kingdom cheered and celebrated, and the young warrior was hailed as a hero. The king was so grateful that he offered her anything she desired, but the young warrior only asked for a small piece of land on which to build her own kingdom.

And so, the young warrior became a queen, and the kingdom prospered under her rule. The people were happy and safe, and the kingdom was at peace. The end.

>Generate a fantasy version of Taken where Liam Neeson is a human king and the kidnappers are orcs, but in the end his daughter decides to stay with them

In this fantasy version of Taken, a human king's daughter is kidnapped while on a trip to a foreign land. The king, a skilled warrior and strategist, immediately sets out to rescue her, using all of his resources and connections to track down the kidnappers and bring his daughter home safely.

The king quickly learns that the kidnappers are a group of ruthless orcs, who have taken the princess to their stronghold in the dark forests of the north as part of a plan to start a war between the human kingdom and the orc tribes. Determined to save his daughter and prevent the war, the king assembles a team of loyal knights and sets out on a dangerous journey to the orc stronghold.

As they travel through the treacherous wilderness, the king and his knights must face countless dangers and obstacles, including fierce battles with orc raiders and treacherous traps set by the enemy. But the king is a master of strategy and martial skill, and he and his knights emerge victorious from every encounter. They also receive valuable help from a traitor within the orc ranks, a former orc who provides them with crucial information in exchange for protection from the other orcs.

Finally, they reach the orc stronghold and launch a fierce attack on the fortress. In a epic battle, the king and his knights fight their way through the orc ranks, using magic and steel to defeat their enemies. They are aided by a powerful magical weapon, a gift from a powerful wizard, that allows them to strike from a distance without being harmed.

But when the king finally reaches the princess, he is shocked to discover that she has fallen in love with one of her orc captors. The orc, a shape-shifter who has taken on the form of a handsome human, has won her affections and she has chosen to stay with him and his tribe. The king is heartbroken, but he knows that his daughter is safe and he must return home without her.

The kingdom is once again safe, but the king is left to mourn the loss of his daughter and the life she could have had. The war between the humans and the orcs is averted, but at a great cost.

name: Anonymous
com: What is the difference between "weird lit" and just plain "horror lit"? I know weird lit is usually focused more on the supernatural, and on evoking a sense of the uncanny whereas most horror is focused on just evoking plain fear, but are there any finer distinctions or clarifications?

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com: Also, where is the line between weird lit and surrealism? Some of Kafka's stories, for example, are just surreal but some of them ("Conversation with the Supplicant" comes most readily to mind), to me, are very weird and give that uncanny feeling that traditional weird lit does.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com: Don't know about Kafka, but I think weird fiction focuses more on "the veil" and merely flirts with what lies beyond it. Gothic is more focused on the past, generally something which there is a degree of knowledge and history about. Weird fiction plays with the unknown to a far greater extent, and likes to do so by tightroping the veil. The Dream Cycle is an exception to this, though, because it penetrates the veil and exhausts the contents of its far side. It still doesn't deal with the past, and serves as more of a mythopoetical exposition for Lovecraft. The sheer outlandishness maybe a more accurate delineation, because I would still consider the Dream Cycle weird fiction as it would fit no other category. The House on the Borderland was regarded as a proto-weird novel and if you read that alongside anything Poe wrote you'll see a monumental break. It's very far-removed from existing themes. Lovecraft sought to derive his horrors from as little previously articulated ones as he could. There's a bit of a transition into scifi horror, with Clark Ashton Smith particularly, that makes a little sense as a progression but I don't think it maintains the spirit of weird fiction.

I think most people would make a common-sense argument, something along the lines of:

When Sentence X says something about the truth or falsehood of Y, X is "setting itself up" in authority over Y. The only reason to "believe it" is if you think it's "more authoritative" than Y. But a thing can't really do that to itself.

Put it another way, if someone says, "Listen, I'm telling the truth", that's not in itself particularly believable. Only something outside a system can comment on the system as a whole.

This used to be called a "theory of types". Probably they have a new name for it now. Academics like to rename things every few years so they can publish more books.

last_replies.name: Anonymouṡ
last_replies.com:
>>21373853
The problem with English is that when something is said in a theoretically "polite" way, more often than not the politeness is meant ironically, and the speaker is being cutting. For example, suppose you had the following exchange at work:

YOUR BOSS: "Could you do X?"
YOU: "Do you need it right away?"
YOUR BOSS: "Well, if it's not too much trouble."

Chances are, that means, "I want it done five minutes ago, or you can start sending out your CVs".

"Kindly do X" would usually be pretty rude, somewhat with the above vibe.

> Speaking of Shakespeare, Shelby Foote, in an interview, placed Proust in the top tier of writers he most admired: “Proust has been the man that hung the moon for me. He’s with Shakespeare in my mind, in the sense of having such a various talent. Whenever you read Proust, for the rest of your life, he’s part of you, the way Shakespeare is part of you. I don’t want to exaggerate, but I truly feel that he is the great writer of the 20th century.”

> Joseph Conrad saw this endless probing as the key to his genius: “Proust’s work . . . is great art based on analysis. I don’t think there is in all creative literature an example of the power of analysis such as this.”

>All its narrative elements—plot, characters, style—create, as Iris Murdoch said of its effect, “the most intense pleasure which one does take in great art.”

> Virginia Woolf’s description of her reaction to Proust’s prose: “Proust so titillates my own desire for expression that I can hardly set out the sentence. Oh if I could write like that! I cry. And at the moment such is the astonishing vibration and saturation and intensification that he procures—there’s something sexual in it—that I feel I can write like that, and seize my pen and then I can’t write like that. Scarcely anyone so stimulates the nerves of language in me: it becomes an obsession. But I must return to Swann.”

> Vladimir Nabokov, who considered it the best novel of its era, described its major themes and effervescent, Mozartean style: “The transmutation of sensation into sentiment, the ebb and tide of memory, waves of emotions such as desire, jealousy, and artistic euphoria—this is the material of this enormous and yet singularly light and translucent work.” In spite of its “enormity” and complexity, Proust’s book has never been out of print and has been translated into well over 40 languages. In Search of Lost Time has not been kept alive by the academy. The work is seldom taught in its entirety in university courses, but maintains its presence among us thanks to readers all over the world who return to it again and again.

A DOZEN MORE SAD SHORT STORIES BY PEOPLE WHO AREN'T RAYMOND CARVER

All Hemingway stories are sad, so take your pick.

— Katina (Roald Dahl)
All of this happened, more or less.


— The Lemon Drop Kid (Damon Runyon)
DR is always so comic and cheery, sort of.

Equal parts sad and unnerving. Basically the quintessential anti-comfy story.

You've already read Bananafish.

Wacky-sad, like a lot of his stuff.

No-one reads DHL any more.

"The Snows Of Kilimanjaro", Bukowski-style.

If you read Moby Dick, I HIGHLY recommend reading it slowly. It's an amazing book (my favorite) but it really needs to be read a chapter at a time and digested. Melville's writing is so fucking autistically dense that if you read it too fast you'll get burnt out within 100 pages.

If you get a copy with footnotes I'd actually advise against reading them on your first read through. Part of the vibe of the book is that Ishmael (the narrator) is this super worldly, well-read "philosopher whaler" who loves to speak in metaphors and allusions to classic literature, greek philosophy, and religion. The reader isn't ACTUALLY expected to understand most of the references... you're mostly meant to sit there and go "damn, who the fuck is this guy? whalers sure are odd and interesting".

Every morning there was more on the pillow. Some black, some blonde, most with a tiny speck at the end that made it clear the entire hair had fallen out. Every so often, there were days when a hand brushed through would find its fingers quickly covered in short, curled baby hairs, and other days so little came out that it was doubtful the hair was falling out at all. In fact, Eol is quite proud of being a dark elf compared to the noldor, when the teleri themselves scorn the Avari for being "dark elves". The telerin identity within beleriand is one of resentfully accepted inferiority towards the noldor, who are clearly technologically, societally, and military more significant than their stunted teleri cousins.

did tolkien mean for Beleriand to be interpreted through the lens of colonialism? The telerin-noldor relationship, as seen from Eol's confrontation with Curufin regarding Aredhel, is one of an "enlightened coloniser" patronizing the savage native, and mocking his culture - for Eol wedded Aredhel in the style of the teleri, not the noldor. Furthermore, when Eol and Turgon meet, Eol denounces the authority of the Noldor to reign Beleriand!

Turgon replies that "by the swords of the Noldor alone are your sunless woods defended. Your freedom to wander there wild you owe to my kin..." The Noldor both threaten and justify with one hand the Teleri; for their "war on angband" was also a Noldor creation! The imposition of Noldor hegemony over the Teleri is naturally unjust. Tolkien, a proud brit, of course portrays the eternal Noldo as upholding not the white mans burden, but the "caliquendi's burden" of educating, protecting, and spreading his values to lesser elves, while simultaneously extracting resources from their land to fuel his own imperial expansion.

Personally, I believe Eol was absolutely vindicated. The second and third kinslayings prove his point about the Noldor and their belligerence. You could call the Noldor the jews of Arda in the sense that they seemed to raise the ire of everyone they met, but simultaneously were fated by god to be the greatest minds in the world and run all elven governments. It is difficult to say definitively whether Eol was right or not, as this interpretation of the Teleri and Noldor in Beleriand is one among many possible ways to understand Tolkien's work. However, it is clear that the relationship between the Teleri and the Noldor is complex and fraught with tensions and conflicts.

The Teleri, who are also known as the Sindar, are a group of Elves who chose to remain in Middle-earth instead of following the Valar to Valinor. They are known for their love of the sea and their skill in crafting and building. The Noldor, on the other hand, are a group of Elves who left Valinor and returned to Middle-earth to fight against the forces of darkness. They are known for their great skill in magic and their love of knowledge and wisdom.

In the confrontation between Eol and Curufin, Eol is portrayed as resentful of the Noldor and their superiority. He sees himself as a "dark Elf" who is inferior to the Noldor, and he scorns the Avari, the "dark Elves" who refused to follow the Valar to Valinor. This resentment is also evident in Eol's marriage to Aredhel, as he chooses to marry her in the style of the Teleri, not the Noldor.

Turgon's response to Eol's denunciation of the Noldor's right to rule Beleriand is telling. He points out that the Noldor have protected the Teleri and their lands, and that their freedom to wander the woods is due to the Noldor's intervention. This suggests that the Noldor see themselves as the protectors and benefactors of the Teleri, even as they impose their own values and culture on them.

It is also worth noting that the Noldor's war against Angband was not just a war for the Teleri, but also a war for the Noldor themselves. The Noldor were driven by their own desire for revenge against Morgoth, and they were willing to use the Teleri and their lands to further their own goals. This could be seen as an example of the Noldor using their superior might and power to impose their will on the Teleri.

Overall, it is clear that the relationship between the Teleri and the Noldor is complex and fraught with tensions and conflicts. Whether or not Eol was right in his assessment of the Noldor's actions and motivations is ultimately up to interpretation.

com:
I just found out about this American writer, who has been grouped with the likes of Roth, Bellow, and Heller. From "The Natural":
>Having no timepiece he appraised the night and decided it was moving toward dawn. As he was looking, there flowed along this bone-white farmhouse with sagging skeletal porch, alone in untold miles of moonlight, and before it this white-faced, long-boned boy whipped with train-whistle yowl a glowing ball to someone hidden under a dark oak, who shot it back without thought, and the kid once more wound and returned. Roy shut his eyes to the sight because if it wasn’t real it was a way he sometimes had of observing himself, just as in this dream he could never shake off—that had hours ago waked him out of sound sleep—of him standing at night in a strange field with a golden baseball in his palm that all the time grew heavier as he sweated to settle whether to hold on
or fling it away. But when he had made his decision it was too heavy to lift or let fall (who wanted a hole that deep?) so he changed his mind to keep it and the thing grew fluffy light, a white rose breaking out of its hide, and all but soared off by itself, but he had already sworn to hang on forever.
I like the elementary simplicity of his prose. What about you?

The book you sent me is one of the tritest and most tedious examples of a trite and tedious genre. The plot and those extravagant “deep” conversations affect me as bad movies do, or the worst plays and stories of Lenid Adreyev, with whom Faulkner has a kind of fatal affinity.

>I imagine that this kind of thing (white trash, velvety Negroes, those bloodhounds out of Uncle Tom’s Cabin melodramas, steadily baying through thousands of swampy books) may be necessary in a social sense, but it is not literature, just as the thousands of stories and novels about downtrodden peasants and fierce ispravniki in Russia, or mystical adventures with the narod (1850-1880), although socially effective and ethically admirable, were not literature. I simply cannot believe that you, with all your knowledge and taste, are not made to squirm by such things as the dialogues between the “positive” characters in Faulkner (and especially those absolutely ghastly italics). last_replies.name: Anonymouṡ
last_replies.com:
>>21368553
Clearly there's no straightforward explanation we can work out, as in a mystery novel. It's not too hard to concoct mundane explanations (he got out beforehand; the records were fudged and he never existed; he killed all the other people on the plane and got out in mid-air, a la Dark Knight, etc).

One sort of bollocksy metaphorical interpretation which might have been floating around (ha, ha) in Cormac's head: the crash of the aircraft represents death, and the missing tenth passenger is whatever you think might survive of you when you die. The soul if you like. If the soul escapes after you die, it leaves the body without any physical evidence of departure, just as the aircraft's door is still sealed. You could argue that the missing flight recorder is the idea that your memories and experiences become part of your soul and will also survive death.

com:
In this thread, we post poems which are among our favorites. Any poem is acceptable, but it should be one which you carry within your heart.

Here's my choice for today:
The Song of Wandering Aengus
W.B. Yeats, c. 1897

I went out to the hazel wood,
Because a fire was in my head,
And cut and peeled a hazel wand,
And hooked a berry to a thread;
And when white moths were on the wing,
And moth-like stars were flickering out,
I dropped the berry in a stream
And caught a little silver trout.

When I had laid it on the floor
I went to blow the fire a-flame,
But something rustled on the floor,
And someone called me by my name:
It had become a glimmering girl
With apple blossom in her hair
Who called me by my name and ran
And faded through the brightening air.

Though I am old with wandering
Through hollow lands and hilly lands,
I will find out where she has gone,
And kiss her lips and take her hands;
And walk among long dappled grass,
And pluck till time and times are done,
The silver apples of the moon,
The golden apples of the sun

This one was very pleasantly written, but when I searched for it the source appearing at the top of the list was marxists.org. As you can imagine, I winced, then scrolled down a ways and clicked Bartleby's option. This only to find the poem itself seems advocative in the implied vein. It isn't that there isn't any increasing imbalance between work and life - there is, but that the imbalance itself originates out of the debasement of money for the sake of an, ironically, communofascist elite class - ever seeking to abscond with our excess, consolidating the resultant power into an transnational structure over which our like shall have no say, but mere nods of ascent. Regardless, though Gilman's sentiments do not resonate with me wholly (I am sympathetic to a degree, but only just), I did like it as a poem. I loved this image - what clever description, "Fierce lamping eyes at nightfall,
A crouching shade by day." Am I wrong to have been colored by the idea she was Marxist? Was she less politically aligned in her motives for this poem?

It's about people in industrial servitude, the wolf being the debt-owners and business-men (or even just the need for money) that would drive workers to exhaustion. If it's been co-opted by marxists, I have no idea if it was the intention of the author, but I love it.

Almost every line is a gem, and she is so good at transcribing the fear of the wolf, and the looming threat of it. The lines you mentioned in the beginning are just awesome, but my favorite bit is actually at the end:

>There's a hot breath at the keyhole
>And a tearing as of teeth!
>Well do I know the bloodshot eyes
>And the dripping jaws beneath!

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
Your death, near now, is of an easy sort.
So slow a fading out brings no real pain.
Breath growing short
Is just uncomfortable. You feel the drain
Of energy, but thought and sight remain:

Enhanced, in fact. When did you ever see
So much sweet beauty as when fine rain falls
On that small tree
And saturates your brick back garden walls,
So many Amber Rooms and mirror halls?

Ever more lavish as the dusk descends
This glistening illuminates the air.
It never ends.
Whenever the rain comes it will be there,
Beyond my time, but now I take my share.

My daughter’s choice, the maple tree is new.
Come autumn and its leaves will turn to flame.
What I must do
Is live to see that. That will end the game
For me, though life continues all the same:

Filling the double doors to bathe my eyes,
A final flood of colours will live on
As my mind dies,
Burned by my vision of a world that shone
So brightly at the last, and then was gone.

here is a quick way to try and train your short term memory.
try to pick out and number 5 things you can see
then number 4 things you touch
then number 3 things you can hear
then number 2 things you can smell
then number 1 you can taste.

At the end of it, try to be able to recall all things in order. between each "set" of senses, it may be fruitful to try and count off the previous set in your head.

good luck and good remembering.

>>21372083
Necessary if you want to study the history of American media or consumerism. Marchand essentially argues that modern advertising corporations (which really got going in the late-19th century) ushered in a new era of hyper consumerism in the United States. The most interesting part of the book are the numerous parallels to revival and evangelical religious movements, particularly the eschatological schizobabble that still resonated with Americans after the Civil War, and the western world at large after WWI.

Essentially, advertising companies saw themselves as herald's of a new age of prosperity. A place in which a mass-produced branded product could cure every ailment or relieve any displeasure. It was a gospel that hallmarked the growth of urban areas, mass-production, and endless consumer choice.

But, as Marchand argues, advertisers realized the
>necessity of associating their selling messages with the values and attitudes already held by their audience

In other words, advertisers don't want to shape fundamental beliefs, but rather exploit already held beliefs to create a positive association to a product. I think this is an important categorical distinction in methodology when it comes to studying the history of American media. Do all forms of media shape fundamental values and beliefs? Or do they hold a mirror to the culture and reflect it in hopes of giving their audience what they want to see? I think this is a fundamental question in understanding everything about today's culture and politics.

Anyway, the chapter names give you a sense of what his arguments are :
>Apostles of Modernity
>Men of the People: The New Professionals
>Keeping the Audience in Focus
>Abandoning the Great Genteel Hope: From Sponsored Radio to the Funny Papers
>The Consumption Ethic: Strategies of Art and Style
>Advertisement as Social Tableaux
>The Great Parables (this is the strongest chapter in the book)
>Visual Cliches: Fantasies and Icons
>Advertising in Overalls: Parables and Visual Cliches in the Depression
>The Therapeutics of Advertising

This book and one by TJ Lears really got me interested in American media history and the philosophy of media. Baudrillard helped deepen my understanding here as well.

> Bahars sister and her friend have decided to make everything out of that little bit of freedom. They walk with hair open around the village and have hired a new Riksha driver, who is supposedly no sandishkor. He will lead us to an isolated beach, Nushin and Sonia want to lie there in bikini under the sun, as if they were in Italy. Nothing of the sad holidays at the beach that Nushin had at the Caspian sea, were women had their own bath resort, built with high walls far into the sea to keep away the looks of other men. Bahar is against. "Is the island our's? Are we here at home?". She falls easily into rage when she is convinced of what she says, especially towards her younger sister. "We can and must fight for our rights in Isfahan and Teheran. Here, other people have to do it."

> Two hours later, Nushin and Sonia in bikini on the beach, six cans of beer next to them. The sea looks like on a post card photo, turquoise, finest sand. They asserted themselves. The winning argument: it is easy to swing big speeches about having respect towards the local culture and customs, when one can return to Vienna in a few weeks and go inside a mixed sauna and march in gay parades without a sorrow. Bahar didn't know an answer.
